qa_pairs.question: What factors led to Tchibo's decision to exit the UK market, and how did this relate to its broader corporate restructuring efforts?
qa_pairs.answer: <statement>Tchibo's decision to exit the UK market was influenced by difficult macroeconomic conditions in Britain and poor market performance, with *Retail Week* describing it as "a glorified pound shop." These challenges led to the closure of half of Tchibo GB's retail stores and the eventual exit from the market by 2009.<cite>[S26][S27][S28][S29]</cite></statement> <statement>The UK market exit aligned with Tchibo's broader corporate restructuring efforts, which included reducing the UK board from 11 to 4 directors and reorganizing head office and field teams. This was part of a 2007 reorganisation program aimed at returning the business to growth by 2010.<cite>[S23][S24][S25]</cite></statement> <statement>Tchibo's restructuring also involved selling its UK leases and closing all physical stores by October 2009, followed by the shutdown of its UK online webstore in 2010, reflecting a strategic shift away from the region.<cite>[S28][S29][S30]</cite></statement>

Passage 1:
[S1] Tchibo


# Tchibo



**Tchibo** is a German chain of coffee retailers and cafés known for its range of non-coffee products that change weekly. [S2] The latter includes: clothing, furniture, household items, electronics and electrical appliances. [S3] In Germany, Tchibo's slogan is "Every week a new world" (German: *Jede Woche eine neue Welt*). [S4] Tchibo has further expanded its product range to sell services such as travel, insurance, and mobile-phone contracts. [S5] With over 1,000 shops, Tchibo is one of Germany's largest retail chains. [S6] The company is headquartered in Hamburg. [S7] Tchibo's coffee is sold in supermarkets and other smaller stores in the United States, Canada, Czechia, Saudi Arabia, Slovakia, Slovenia, Bulgaria, Romania, Turkey, Hungary, Ukraine, Syria, Jordan, ~~Russia~~, United Arab Emirates, Poland, Ireland, United Kingdom, Switzerland, Liechtenstein, and Lebanon. [S8] It is also sold online. [S9] ## History


### Founding

Tchibo was founded in 1949 in Hamburg by Max Herz and Carl Tchilinghiryan, and still maintains its headquarters in the north of the city. [S10] The name Tchibo is an abbreviation for Tchiling and *Bohnen* (coffee beans). [S11] During its formative years, Tchibo concentrated on a mail-order service of freshly roasted coffee beans, processed in the company's own roasting facility in the Hamburg district of Hoheluft. [S12] ### Expansion

In 1977, Tchibo purchased shares of Beiersdorf and in 1980 became the majority shareholder of the Hamburg cigarette producer Reemtsma. [S13] The Reemtsma stake was sold in 2002 to Imperial Tobacco for €5.2 billion. [S14] In 1986, they tried their luck in the video game console market and released the Tele-Fever home video game console. [S15] It sold only very few units. [S16] After buying its rival Eduscho in 1997, Tchibo became the market leader in Germany with 20%. [S17] In the 1990s, Tchibo began to expand to countries outside Germany and now has shops in Switzerland, Liechtenstein, Austria, the Netherlands, Poland, Hungary, Slovakia, the Czech Republic and Turkey. [S18] Entry into the US market was planned in the early 2000s, but later cancelled. [S19] As of mid-2020 Tchibo operates a mail order business in the United States selling ground and whole-bean coffee as well as proprietary coffee makers. [S20] Tchibo sold the cigarette brand Davidoff to the UK-based company Imperial Tobacco for €540 million. [S21] in 2006; the rights for the brand *Davidoff café* remained with Tchibo. [S22] Tchibo has started distribution of its brand *Davidoff café* to the US. [S23] ### Reorganisation

The company presented a reorganisation programme to its employees at a staff meeting on 7 December 2007, with the aim of returning the business to growth by 2010.ᶜⁱᵗᵃᵗⁱᵒⁿ ⁿᵉᵉᵈᵉᵈ

In the UK, following a consultation period, Tchibo GB decided to close half of its retail stores and re-structure the head office and field teams. [S24] The UK board was reduced from 11 directors to 4. [S25] In November 2008, a Tchibo spokesman announced that the concessions in Somerfield and Sainsbury's supermarkets would close in 2009, blaming difficult macroeconomic conditions in Britain. [S26] Tchibo's lack of success in the British market was summarised by *Retail Week* as due to it being "a glorified pound shop". [S27] In early 2009, the company confirmed it would leave the UK market, by selling its leases. [S28] All of the Tchibo GB stores were closed by the end of October 2009. [S29] The UK online webstore followed on 1 September 2010. [S30] A "new and improved" Tchibo Online Shop was launched in the UK on 28 June 2016

In August 2016, Tchibo acquired Scotland based roasting company Matthew Algie. [S31] ## Corporate structure

Tchibo is owned by Maxingvest AG, which changed its name from Tchibo Holding AG in 2007. [S32] It is 100% owned by three members of the Herz family, Ingeburg Herz (Max Herz's widow), and two of her sons, Michael Herz and Wolfgang Herz. [S33] In 2003, they bought out their brother, Gunter, and sister, Daniela Herz-Schnoekel. [S34] Their brother Joachim died in a motorboat accident in 2008.

Passage 2:
[S35] Maxingvest AG is the largest shareholder of the listed company Beiersdorf. [S36] In 2002, Tchibo had 850 shops and 22,000 so-called *Frische-Depots* in bread shops and supermarkets, where shelves bearing the company's "brand" sell packaged coffee (with customer-operated coffee grinders provided in some locations) alongside non-food articles such as clothes and accessories, as well as sporting and household goods.
